Fig. 1 (a-e) Representative SEM images of different MOFs, including Ni-M, Ni2Zn1-M, Ni1Zn1-M, Ni1Zn2-M, and Zn-M, wherein "M" represents MOFs, (f-j) representative SEM images of the corresponding oxide products, including Ni-MC, Ni2Zn1-MC, Ni1Zn1-MC, Ni1Zn2-MC, and Zn-MC, wherein "MC" represents MOF after calcination. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 XRD patterns of the calcined products (i.e., NiZn-MC) from the MOF precursors. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 SEM images and the corresponding EDX elemental maps of different metal oxide samples (a) Ni-MC, (b) Ni2Zn1-MC, (c) Ni1Zn1-MC, (d) Ni1Zn2-MC, and (e) Zn-MC. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Catalytic deoxygenation performance of stearic acid over NiZn-MC with different Ni/Zn molar proportions. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 High-resolution XPS spectra of Ni-MC, Ni2Zn1-MC, Ni1Zn1-MC, Ni1Zn2-MC, and Zn-MC samples, (a-d) Ni 2p region and (e-h) Zn 2p region. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 SEM images at different magnifications of (a, e) CB, (b, f) 0.2Ni1Zn1-MC@CB, (c, g) 0.6Ni1Zn1-MC@CB, and (d, h) 1.0Ni1Zn1-MC@CB. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 XRD patterns of (a) CB, (b) 0.2Ni1Zn1-MC@CB, (c) 0.6Ni1Zn1-MC@CB, and (d) 1.0Ni1Zn1-MC@CB. China ⁎ Corresponding authors. 1 These two authors contributed equally to this work 2 0000–0002-6337–3758 Herein, NiZn bimetallic oxides derived from calcination treatment of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) were successfully loaded onto the carbon black waste as support obtained from the oil refinery. The resulting hybrids could serve as environmentally friendly and cost-effective catalysts for the deoxygenation of biomass-derived fatty acids under an inert atmosphere. An online pyrolysis-gas chromatography/mass spectrometry (Py-GC/MS) system was employed to evaluate their deoxygenation performance. The optimized catalysts demonstrated remarkably high stearic acid conversion of 99.6% and selectivity towards C8-C17 olefins of 57.2%. Furthermore, these catalysts with varying metal loadings also exhibited excellent efficiency in deoxygenation reactions of other types of fatty acids, such as myristic acid and palmitic acid, achieving conversion exceeding 85% and selectivities towards olefins of ca. 50%. When converting coconut oil, the supported NiZn bimetallic oxides showed excellent selectivity towards olefins (>60%). Furthermore, in-situ DRIFTS results suggest that fatty alcohols might be the key intermediates in the deoxidation reactions of fatty acid. This study not only demonstrates the great potential for obtaining valuable chemicals from biomass but also provides some insights into the fabrication of catalyst materials by using industrial solid waste. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Carbonaceous residue Metal oxide Stearic acid Deoxygenation reaction Resource utilization Olefin Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Rapid industrialization and increasing energy consumption lead to anthropogenic climate change and the accumulation of large amounts of industrial waste, which pose a huge threat to human health [1]. Accordingly, various technologies have been developed to utilize renewable biomass resources to produce value-added biofuels or biochemicals [2,3]. For instance, the deoxygenation of biomass-derived fatty acids into hydrocarbons (olefins, alkanes, aromatics) offers an appealing and sustainable solution for meeting global energy and chemical demands [4]. As an important raw chemical, long-chain alkenes produced by the deoxygenation of fatty acids have a wider range of applications than alkanes due to their functional CC bonds. In particular, the long-chain alkenes, derived from the deoxygenation of fatty acid, possess broad applications in the synthesis of polymers, plasticizers, lubricants, and additives [5]. The decarbonylation reaction of fatty acid to produce unsaturated olefins (CnH2n) and the decarboxylation reaction to produce alkanes (CnH2n+2) are two main routes in the catalytic deoxygenation process for the fatty acids [6]. Both reactions are endothermic, and the oxygens are removed in the forms of CO and water or CO2. From a thermodynamic perspective, the selective production of unsaturated olefins is more challenging as the cleaving of the C-O bond (461.5 kJ/mol) is higher than the C-C bond (384.9 kJ/mol) [7,8]. Currently, precious metal-based catalysts (such as Pt, Pd, Ru, and Rh) have been widely used in the deoxygenation of fatty acids, esters, and glycerides [9–13]. Alternatively, the transition metal sulfides, phosphates, carbides, and zeolites, such as MoS2 [14], WP [15], Mo2C [16], SAPO-11 [17], MCM-41 [18], and ZSM-5 [19], have also been developed for biofuel production from renewable biomass source (fats and oils). In recent years, extensive research has been conducted on the utilization of transition metal oxides (including Ni, Co, W, Mo, Cu, Fe, Zn, etc.), in the deoxygenation reactions of fatty acids. These transition metal oxides have demonstrated remarkable capabilities in cleaving or isomerizing the carbon chains, with excellent selectivity towards hydrocarbon products [20–23]. Among them, nickel-based and zinc-based catalysts with high availability and low cost have shown excellent catalytic performance [23,24]. It is well-known that carrier materials play an important role in the dispersion state and surface chemistry of the metallic active sites via chemical interactions, thus affecting catalytic activity and product selectivity [25,26]. Herein, carbon black waste (denoted as CB), a type of petroleum coke obtained from the oil refinery industry, was explored as carrier material for loading NiZn bimetallic oxide for the deoxygenation of fatty acids. There are abundant oxygen-containing groups on the surface of the acid-treated solid waste CB, which not only favor the dispersion of metal oxides but also show good deoxygenation performance [27]. On the other hand, the thermal decomposition of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) has been proved as an ideal method to fabricate highly dispersion metal oxides, which have many advantages such as tailorable composition, definable pore size, and high surface area [20]. The flow chart of the catalyst preparation route in this work is shown in Scheme 1. In the process, PVP was used as a structure-directing agent to regulate the structure of MOFs [28]. First, bimetallic NiZn-MOFs were prepared and subjected to calcination to obtain NiZn metal oxides. Next, the target catalysts were fabricated by depositing the oxides onto CB support via ultrasonication [29]. Analytical pyrolysis-gas chromatography/mass spectrometry (Py-GC/MS) was used for the evaluation of the catalytic performance towards the rapid pyrolysis of fatty acids. The catalytic performance was optimized by investigating the effects of the catalyst's chemical composition and reaction conditions. This study aims to explore the utilization of sustainable renewable resources for producing value-added biochemicals. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemicals and materials Carbon black (CB) waste was collected from an oil refinery in Quanzhou, China. The following chemicals were used as received without further purification: sodium hydroxide (NaOH, ≥98%, Greagent), nitric acid (HNO3, 65–68 wt%, Macklin), nickel chloride hexahydrate (NiCl2·6 H2O, 99%, Adamas), zinc acetate dihydrate (Zn(CH3COO)2·2 H2O, ≥ 99%, Xilong Science), 3,5-pyridinedicarboxylic acid (3,5-H2pdc, ≥98%, Adamas), polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP, MW: 45,000–58,000, K30, Adamas), stearic acid (C18H36O2, ≥99%, Macklin), palmitic acid (C16H32O2, ≥99%, Macklin), myristic acid (C14H28O2, ≥99%, Macklin), lauric acid (C12H24O2, 98%, Macklin), methyl stearate (C19H38O2, 99%, Macklin), oleic acid (C18H34O2, 98%, Macklin), coconut acid (chemically pure, Aladdin), and soybean acid (reagent grade, Aladdin). 2.2 Preparation of NiZn bimetallic oxides (NiZn-MC) For the preparation of MOF templates, 3,5-H2pdc was used as the organic linker. Meanwhile, NiCl2·6 H2O and Zn(CH3COO)2·2 H2O were used as the metal ions of Ni and Zn respectively. In a typical procedure, NiCl2·6 H2O (0.107 g, 0.45 mmol), Zn(CH3COO)2·2 H2O (0.099 g, 0.45 mmol), 3,5-H2pdc (0.15 g, 0.9 mmol), NaOH (0.036 g, 0.9 mmol), and PVP (0.02 g) were dissolved in 20 mL of water. The mixed solution was stirred at room temperature for 24 h before collection of the product by centrifugation and washing three times with water and ethanol. After drying at 60 °C for 12 h, the obtained MOF powder was labeled as Ni1Zn1-M, which was then calcined in the air (500 °C, 4 h) to obtain MOF-derived oxides (labeled as Ni1Zn1-MC). In general, molar ratios of NiCl2·6 H2O and Zn(CH3COO)2·2 H2O (nNi + nZn= 0.9 mmol, Ni/Zn ratio = 0:1, 2:1, 1:1, 1:2, 1:0) could be controlled to prepare different MOF precursors (Ni-M, Ni2Zn1-M, Ni1Zn1-M, Ni1Zn2-M, and Zn-M). After calcining the different MOF precursors, the corresponding metal oxides were recorded as Ni-MC, Ni2Zn1-MC, Ni1Zn1-MC, Ni1Zn2-MC, and Zn-MC for subsequent use. 2.3 Synthesis of supported catalysts First, the as-received wet CB was dried in an oven at 150 °C for 12 h to remove the moisture. Then, 0.3 g of dried CB was dispersed in 60 mL of HNO3 solution (0.5 mol/L) and stirred for 3 h at room temperature to remove the contaminated metal components. After thoroughly washing with water 4 times and drying at 150 °C for 12 h, the cleaned CB was then ground with a mortar and pestle to obtain CB fine powder. Subsequently, the supported catalysts were prepared by physical mixing of CB support and NiZn-MC in aqueous medium. The mixture was subjected to ultrasonic treatment for 4 h to uniformly load the NiZn-MC on the CB support. Following centrifugation, the catalyst was subjected to solid-liquid separation and dried at 60 °C for a duration of 12 h. The obtained supported catalysts were labeled as nNiZn-MC@CB (n = 0.2, 0.6, and 1.0), where n represents different load amounts of Ni1Zn1-MC on the CB support. 2.4 Characterization methods Various analytical techniques were used to characterize the designed catalyst materials. For instance, scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Hitachi SU5000) was employed to examine the surface morphology and microstructure. The chemical compositions were analyzed using energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX, Oxford X-Maxn). The metal loading contents on the catalysts were determined by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES, PerkinElmer Optima 7300DV system). The phase composition was determined through X-ray diffraction (XRD) using the Rigaku Smart Lab instrument, operated at 30 mA and 40 kV with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54182 Å). The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were achieved using a JEM-F200 instrument (JEOL). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed using the Shimadzu DTG-60 H thermal analyzer, with a heating rate of 10 °C/min under air atmosphere, ranging from room temperature to 800 °C. The N2 physisorption isotherms and pore size distributions were conducted on the Quantachrome Autosorb-IQ system at 77 K. The Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy of adsorbed pyridine (Py-FTIR) was performed on an FTIR instrument (Nicolet iS-50, Thermo Fisher). In-situ DRIFTS experiments were performed on the same FTIR instrument coupled with a ZnSe window reaction chamber from Harrick and a KBr beam splitter. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was used to analyze the surface valence states of the prepared samples, utilizing the Thermo ESCALAB 250XI instrument. 2.5 Catalytic performance evaluation method The catalytic pyrolysis of fatty acids was performed via a mini pyrolysis device (Rx-3050TR, Frontier Lab, Japan). The two-stage fixed bed reactors are vertically connected and carried out at different temperatures (see the apparatus drawing in Fig. S1). In the first reactor, 0.50 mg of stearic acid was loaded in the sampler. In the second reactor, a quartz tube (inner diameter of 3 mm and length of 78 mm) was used to load 20 mg of the prepared catalysts sandwiched between two quartz cotton layers. An online gas chromatography/mass spectrometry (GC/MS, 8860/5977B, Agilent), with an HP-5MS chromatographic column (30 m × 0.250 mm × 0.25 μm, Agilent), was employed to analyze the products. The obtained volatile matters were identified by comparing mass spectra with the NIST MS library. The detailed operation and analysis conditions of Py-GC/MS were also described in other works [30,31]. The experiments were conducted in duplicate or more to minimize experimental errors, and the average of the data was taken. Herein, C8-C17 alkanes, C8-C17 olefins, aromatics, and oxygenated compounds present in the product of the conversion are labeled as C8 0-C17 0, C8 =-C17 =, Aro, and Oxc, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of NiZn-MC SEM images of the MOF precursors (NiZn-M) depict the uniform rod-like structure ( Fig. 1a-e), which exhibits a relatively smooth surface. After calcination, the derived NiZn-MC retained the one-dimensional rod-like structure (Fig. 1f-j), although with a reduced length of approximately 50%. This was due to the removal of organic linkers during the calcination treatment. Furthermore, N2 physisorption isotherms of NiZn-MC display type-IV behavior with evident hysteresis loops (Fig. S2), indicating the presence of mesopores [32,33]. The pore volume of the Ni1Zn1-MC was even five times that of Ni1Zn1-M (0.15 vs. 0.03 cm3/g). The thermal behavior of Ni1Zn1-M and Ni1Zn1-MC was further investigated by TG analysis (Fig. S3). The metal oxides generated from the thermal decomposition of MOFs exhibit remarkable stability, while Ni1Zn1-M underwent a weight loss of approximately 76.1% upon complete thermal decomposition, primarily due to the decomposition of organic components [34,35]. It can be seen that calcination treatment at 500 °C would completely decompose Ni1Zn1-M and form the desired oxides. Fig. 2 depicts the XRD pattern of the catalyst samples. The five distinct XRD peaks at 37.2°, 43.3°, 62.9°, 75.4° and 79.4° of Ni-MC can be assigned to the (111), (200), (220), (311), and (222) planes of NiO (JCPDS card No. 71–1179), respectively [36]. In the Zn-MC sample, the XRD peaks at 31.7°, 34.4°, and 36.2° corresponded to the (100), (002), and (101) planes of ZnO (JCPDS card No. 89–1397), respectively [37]. As varying ratios of Ni2+ and Zn2+ in the synthetic MOFs, mixed metal oxides were obtained, such as Ni2Zn1-MC, Ni1Zn1-MC, and Ni1Zn2-MC, which exhibited both ZnO (JCPDS card No. 89–1397) and Ni0.8Zn0.2O phase (JCPDS card No. 75–0271) [38]. This suggests that the NiZn-MC consists of both Ni0.8Zn0.2O and ZnO phases. As compared to pure NiO, all diffraction peaks in Ni0.8Zn0.2O were observed to shift toward lower angles, indicating increased lattice parameters [39]. This can be attributed to the partial substitution of Ni2+ by larger-sized Zn2+ [40]. Moreover, the peak intensity of the Ni0.8Zn0.2O phase was found to decrease as increasing the Zn/Ni molar fraction. Fig. 3 shows the EDX elemental maps of the prepared NiZn-MC, suggesting the uniform dispersion of Ni, Zn, and O elements across the whole structure. ICP-OES analysis revealed that the molar ratios of Ni/Zn in Ni2Zn1-MC, Ni1Zn1-MC, and Ni1Zn2-MC were approximately 2, 1, and 0.5, respectively (Table S1). These ratios closely matched the Ni/Zn molar ratios of the raw metal salts employed in the synthesis process of MOFs. 3.2 Deoxygenation of stearic acid by NiZn-MC Fig. 4 illustrates the deoxygenation performance of stearic acid over various NiZn-MC using a Py-GC-MS device. As the Ni/Zn molar ratio decreases, both the conversion and deoxygenation of stearic acid were found to increase gradually. Meanwhile, the selectivities of alkanes and aromatics were found to increase. The conversion of stearic acid increased significantly from 12.1% to 89.3%, and the deoxygenation efficiency increased from 5.0% to 42.6%. In addition, the selectivity of C8-C17 olefins was the highest over Ni2Zn1-MC catalyst, reaching 41.7%. These results indicate that the designed bimetallic oxide catalysts are beneficial for the generation of olefins from the catalytic pyrolysis of fatty acids. As can be seen, the Ni component favored the formation of olefin products, exhibiting a selectivity of 32.9% for olefins, whereas the selectivities for alkanes and aromatics were only 3.0% and 5.2%, respectively. On the other hand, the Zn component promoted the catalytic pyrolysis of stearic acid with a high conversion of 89.3% and a deoxygenation efficiency of 42.6%. The selectivities of olefins, alkanes, and aromatics were 19.0%, 13.0%, and 15.7%, respectively. It is worth noting that the catalytic performance of NiZn-MC is superior to that of monometallic oxide (NiO and ZnO). In particular, Ni1Zn1-MC exhibited a conversion of 42.1% and a deoxygenation efficiency of 22.6%. Furthermore, the selectivity for olefins and aromatics reached 32.1% and 13.8%, respectively. 3.3 XPS analysis of NiZn-MC The chemical composition and chemical states of Ni-MC, Zn-MC, and NiZn-MC samples were examined by XPS characterization. As shown in Fig. 5, the deconvoluted peaks of Ni 2p could be assigned to Ni 2p 3/2 and Ni 2p 1/2. The Ni 2p 3/2 shows two major peaks within the range of 853.2–853.6 eV and 854.9–855.4 eV, corresponding to the Ni-O and Ni-OH species, respectively. This confirms the successful formation of the NiO phase in the sample [41]. The peaks at 872.4–872.8 eV and 870.6–870.9 eV are related to Ni 2p 1/2. The existence of Ni3+ is confirmed by the appearance of the peak of Ni 2p 3/2 at 854.9–855.4 eV and the Ni 2p 1/2 peak at 870.6–871.0 eV, which are assigned to the Ni2O3 phase [42,43]. The Ni 2p 3/2 peak at 853.2–853.6 eV and the 2p 1/2 peak at 870.6–870.9 eV represent the formation of Ni2+ in NiO [44]. It has been shown that the Ni (II) site can promote the desorption of olefin, and thus inhibit the side reactions [45]. Therefore, Ni (II) site could enhance the selectivity of olefin products. Furthermore, satellite peaks are observed alongside the main peaks, which can be attributed to shake-up processes [43,46]. These satellite peaks are evident at 880.3–880.6 eV and 877.1–877.5 eV, as well as at 863.6–864.1 eV and 860.1–860.6 eV, respectively. Fig. 5e-h display the XPS Zn 2p spectra of the four samples, which exhibit two distinctive peaks at approximately 1044.4–1044.8 eV and 1021.4–1021.8 eV, corresponding to the Zn 2p 1/2 and Zn 2p 3/2, respectively. The spin-orbit splitting of Zn 2p 3/2 and Zn 2p 1/2 branches is 23.0 eV, indicating the presence of Zn2+ in the composites [47]. The introduction of Zn2+ serving as Lewis acid sites can enhance the acidity of the catalysts, facilitating the breaking of C-C bonds. Meanwhile, the introduction of Zn2+ can effectively inhibit coke formation and improve catalytic stability [48]. These findings provide further verification of the coexistence of both NiO and Ni0.8Zn0.2O phases within the synthesized NiZn-MC products. 3.4 Characterization of supported NiZn-MC@CB SEM images of the supported NiZn-MC@CB can be found in Fig. 6. It can be observed that the morphology of the CB support remains largely unchanged after the loading of NiZn-MC. The CB support manifests a flocculent appearance with a porous structure, characterized by randomly stacked particles. Furthermore, the rod-like structure of the NiZn-MC (marked by the red dotted lines in Fig. 6) remains intact. Fig. S4 shows the EDX elemental maps of the four samples. Specifically, the CB support mainly consists of carbon (depicted by the purple area) with negligible amounts of Ni and Zn elements. In contrast, the element mapping of the nNi1Zn1-MC@CB samples, confirms the presence of Ni, Zn, and O elements as well as the uniform distribution of Ni1Zn1-MC on the CB support. The NiZn-MC@CB samples with different metal loadings were further characterized by the XRD. The XRD pattern of the CB support reveals a prominent diffraction peak corresponding to the (002) crystal plane of the graphitic structure at approximately 2θ ≈ 26°. The emergence of this peak can be attributed to the interlayer stacking of carbonaceous structures, with its intensity positively correlating to an augmented number of carbon layers [49]. Additionally, the XRD pattern in Fig. 7a displays diffraction peak at around 2θ ≈ 43°, which is indicative of the parallel stacking of hexagonal network layers in the carbon structure. However, the low intensity indicates diminished crystallinity in the carbonaceous material. The change of the (110) diffraction peak can hardly be observed at 2θ ≈ 77° [50]. Obviously, with an increase in the mass of Ni1Zn1-MC loaded onto the CB support, the diffraction peaks due to Ni0.8Zn0.2O (JCPDS card No. 75–0271) and ZnO (JCPDS card No. 89–1397) were found. Furthermore, as shown in Fig. S5, the high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) images of the 0.2Ni1Zn1-MC@CB sample exhibited lattice fringes of 0.21, 0.25, and 0.26 nm which were assigned to (200) plane of Ni0.8Zn0.2O phase, (101) and (002) planes of ZnO phase [38], respectively. The thermal properties of the nNi1Zn1-MC@CB under air atmosphere were studied by the TGA technique ( Fig. 8). The initial weight loss observed at temperatures above 100 °C is related to the removal of moisture and other volatile impurities that are adsorbed on the sample surface [34,51]. The second stage of weight loss can be attributed to the oxidative decomposition of carbon [52]. At the 800 °C, the CB support exhibits the lowest residual weight (0.7 wt%), while the residual weights of 0.2Ni1Zn1-MC@CB, 0.6Ni1Zn1-MC@CB and 1.0Ni1Zn1-MC@CB samples were measured at 11.8%, 33.4%, and 47.0%, respectively. These results closely align with the mass proportion of the metallic components in the precursor materials, indicating that Ni1Zn1-MC is almost completely loaded on the CB support. Subsequently, the 0.2Ni1Zn1-MC@CB catalyst and CB support were characterized by ICP and N2 physisorption techniques. The ICP results are presented in Table S2, showing that Ni (7.89 wt%) and Zn content (8.52 wt%) were present in the 0.2Ni1Zn1-MC@CB composite. While negligible amounts of metals were found in pure CB support. The N2 physisorption results indicate that both samples present type Ⅳ curves with an H2-type hysteresis loop (Fig. S6), according to the IUPAC classification [32]. The specific surface areas of CB and 0.2Ni1Zn1-MC@CB were determined to be 241 and 165 m2/g, respectively (Table S3). Meanwhile, the decrease in pore volume observed in the 0.2Ni1Zn1-MC@CB sample can be attributed to the loading of the Ni1Zn1-MC into the pores of the CB support. High-resolution XPS characterization of the Ni 2p peak of 0.2Ni1Zn1-MC@CB confirms the presence of Ni2+ (Fig. S7a), with binding energies of 854.3 eV (Ni 2p 3/2) and 871.9 eV (Ni 2p 1/2), respectively. Characteristic satellite peaks for the 2p 3/2 and 2p 1/2 peaks were observed at 861.7, 866.3, 878.5, and 881.7 eV, which is consistent with previous results in Fig. 5. Similarly, the XPS peak at 1022.7 and 1045.7 eV are attributed to the 2p 3/2 and 2p 1/2 of Zn, respectively, which is consistent with the standard binding energy of Zn2+ with a spin-orbit splitting of 23.0 eV. 3.5 Effect of NiZn-MC loading amount on deoxygenation performance As shown in Fig. 9, it is observed that varying the loading of metal oxides indeed impacts the catalytic pyrolysis process. The evaluation results showed that compared to Ni1Zn1-MC alone (conversion of 42.1%), nNi1Zn1-MC@CB achieves stearic acid conversion of 100%. Meanwhile, there is also a significant enhancement in the selectivity towards alkanes and aromatics, rising from 7.7% to 57.5% and 13.8–19.5%, respectively. CB support alone demonstrates remarkable deoxygenation performance, achieving a deoxygenation efficiency of 96.4%. The catalytic activity of CB support can be attributed to the presence of rich oxygen-containing groups on the surface [53]. However, the CB support alone exhibits low selectivity towards olefins. It is determined that the optimal mass ratio of CB support to Ni1Zn1-MC is 5:1 (that is, 0.2Ni1Zn1-MC@CB). The resultant 0.2Ni1Zn1-MC@CB catalyst exhibits improved selectivity for olefins (29.3%) while maintaining selectivity for alkanes and aromatics of 51.4% and 19.3% respectively. This indicates the important role of Ni1Zn1-MC in promoting olefin products. In addition, when the mass proportion of Ni1Zn1-MC/CB is 1 (i.e., 1.0Ni1Zn1-MC@CB), there was a decrease in both the selectivity of olefins (20.5%) and the deoxygenation efficiency (82.7%), which may be due to the shielding of active sites on Ni1Zn1-MC and CB support [54,55]. 3.6 Optimization of reaction conditions of deoxygenation reactions The deoxygenation conditions of 0.2Ni1Zn1-MC@CB catalyst were investigated and optimized. As shown in Fig. 10a, the effect of reaction temperature on the conversion of stearic acid is negligible. It is noteworthy that an increase in reaction temperature from 385 to 445 °C leads to complete conversion (∼100%) of stearic acid. At the temperature of 405 °C, the selectivity towards olefins was 29.3%, whereas the selectivity towards alkanes reached 51.4%. It was found that the product distribution could be regulated by adjusting the amount of catalyst (Fig. 10b). As expected, the reaction cannot occur spontaneously without the catalyst with a negligible conversion of 0.3%. As the catalyst dosage increased, the conversion of stearic acid was close to 100%, but there was a decline in the selectivity of olefins. Specifically, the lowest olefin selectivity of 28.1% was achieved at a catalyst dosage of 15 mg. With the increase in catalyst dosage, the pyrolysis products can continue to be pyrolyzed and undergo isomerization, addition, and aromatization reactions to produce a variety of by-products [56]. By setting the reaction temperature at 405 °C and employing a catalyst amount of 5 mg, the catalytic performance reached its optimum, with 99.6% conversion of stearic acid, 57.2% selectivity of olefins, and 39.6% selectivity toward alkanes. The catalytic performance reported in the literature regarding the deoxygenation of oils and fats to olefins was summarized in Table S4. It can be seen that the prepared 0.2Ni1Zn1 @CB exhibited excellent catalytic activity, which was superior to most of the reported catalysts. Fig. 10c depicts the Py-FTIR spectra of 0.2Ni1Zn1-MC@CB, indicating the existence of both Lewis acid and Brønsted acid sites. For instance, the IR bands around 1437 and 1445 cm−1 are attributed to Lewis acid sites, which are active sites for fatty acid catalytic deoxygenation [57,58]. Meanwhile, the IR band near 1537 cm−1 can be attributed to the Brønsted acid sites, which contributed not only to the deoxygenation reaction but also can also the cracking reaction of long-chain olefins [59,60]. Furthermore, in-situ DRIFTS was performed to determine stearic acid adsorption and conversion behaviors over the designed catalyst (Fig. 10d). The time evolution of DRIFT spectra indicated a strong aliphatic alcohol characteristic band at about 3400 cm−1, which gradually decreased with increasing reaction time [8]. This suggests that fatty alcohols might be the key intermediates in fatty acid deoxidation reactions. The obtained spectra showed a band at around 2020 cm−1, corresponding to CO [61]. At the reaction time of 1.6 min, the hydroxyl group peak disappeared, and the band at around 1640 cm−1 was found, corresponding to the stretching vibration of the CC bond [8]. This confirms that long-chain olefin products are formed via the decarbonylation of fatty acids. The IR band observed at 2855 and 2926 cm−1 can be assigned to the stretching of the methylene (-CH2) and methyl (-CH3) groups in olefins [62]. Meanwhile, the two distinct bands at 1397 and 1453 cm−1 are gradually enhanced, which may be the result of the cleavage of long-chain olefins into short-chain olefins [59]. Moreover, to investigate the effect of carbon chain length on the catalytic performance of 0.2Ni1Zn1-MC@CB, deoxygenation reactions of different fatty acids were performed, including lauric acid (C12H24O2), myristic acid (C14H28O2), palmitic acid (C16H32O2) and stearic acid (C18H36O2). From Fig. 11, both conversion and olefins selectivity were increased as increasing the carbon chain length of fatty acids (from C12 to C18). Compared with the product composition using lauric acid as the feedstock, the conversion of stearic acid increased from 61.8% to 99.6%, indicating that saturated fatty acids with longer carbon chains were easier to convert. In terms of the product composition, olefins were the major product with the highest selectivity among various deoxygenation reactions which varied from 44.0% to 57.2% when using different fatty acids. Meanwhile, the selectivity towards oxygenated compounds decreased from 18.5% to 2.0%. Furthermore, the deoxygenation reactions of other substrates, such as unsaturated fatty acids (methyl stearate, oleic acid) and vegetable oils (coconut oil and soybean oil), were also conducted. As can be seen from Fig. 12, the conversion of methyl stearate was significantly lower than that of stearic acid (55.0% vs. 99.6%), which may be due to the high oxygen content and the existence of ester groups. Meanwhile, the selectivity for olefins reached 42.6%. The conversion of oleic acid (73.7%) was also lower than that of stearic acid (99.6%) due to the existence of the CC bond, but the selectivity of olefins was enhanced (57.2% vs. 65.7%). The conversions of both soybean oil and coconut oil were high (93.6% vs. 96.1%). Regarding the product distribution, as compared to using soybean oil as the feedstock, the selectivity of olefins and alkanes from catalytic pyrolysis of coconut oil increased from 32.6% to 60.3% and from 23.8% to 31.5%, respectively. Meanwhile, the selectivity of aromatic hydrocarbons was negligible (∼1.0%). These outcomes demonstrate the excellent deoxygenation performance of our designed catalysts which has the potential for olefin production from oils and fats. 4 Conclusions In this work, NiZn bimetallic oxides were prepared from NiZn-MOF via calcination treatment which can be loaded on the carbon black (CB) waste support to prepare the NiZn-MC@CB catalysts. The obtained catalysts demonstrated high activity for the deoxygenation reaction of fatty acid to olefin in solvent-free and hydrogen-free conditions. The addition of CB can promote metal oxide dispersion and increase the deoxygenation performance of fatty acids under N2 atmosphere. The experimental results evidenced that 0.2Ni1Zn1-MC@CB (mass ratio of Ni1Zn1-MC/CB is 1:5) catalyst exhibited good deoxygenation performance with higher conversion of fatty acid and olefins selectivity than the pure Ni1Zn1-MC and CB. Under the optimum reaction temperature of 405 °C and catalyst dosage of 5 mg, the NiZn-MC@CB catalysts exhibited outstanding performance with stearic acid conversion of 99.6% and selectivity of 57.2% for olefins. The catalysts were also effective for the deoxygenation of vegetable oils such as coconut oil, with conversion of 93.6% and high selectivity of 60.3% for olefin products (C8-C17). Therefore, our designed NiZn-MC@CB catalyst showed great potential for the production of valuable chemicals from fatty acids, and this is a good demonstration of the resource utilization of various carbon-containing solid wastes for the fabrication of carbon-supported catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Herein, NiZn bimetallic oxides derived from calcination treatment of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) were successfully loaded onto the carbon black waste as support obtained from the oil refinery. The resulting hybrids could serve as environmentally friendly and cost-effective catalysts for the deoxygenation of biomass-derived fatty acids under an inert atmosphere. An online pyrolysis-gas chromatography/mass spectrometry (Py-GC/MS) system was employed to evaluate their deoxygenation performance. The optimized catalysts demonstrated remarkably high stearic acid conversion of 99.6% and selectivity towards C8-C17 olefins of 57.2%. Furthermore, these catalysts with varying metal loadings also exhibited excellent efficiency in deoxygenation reactions of other types of fatty acids, such as myristic acid and palmitic acid, achieving conversion exceeding 85% and selectivities towards olefins of ca. 50%. When converting coconut oil, the supported NiZn bimetallic oxides showed excellent selectivity towards olefins (>60%). Furthermore, in-situ DRIFTS results suggest that fatty alcohols might be the key intermediates in the deoxidation reactions of fatty acid. This study not only demonstrates the great potential for obtaining valuable chemicals from biomass but also provides some insights into the fabrication of catalyst materials by using industrial solid waste.
coredata.dc:title: Fabrication of NiZn bimetallic oxides catalysts supported on carbon black waste for catalytic pyrolysis of fatty acid
